title: Time is right
initialText: Overcast.\ Just as gloomy as always.
The bulb in the stairwell struggled to give the last bit of dim, incandescent light.
Climbing the last flight of stairs to my floor, I noticed a faint but slowly stronger cigar scent.
It is certainly rare to find such a luxury in an almost falling apartment building like this.
Resided most by unemployed drunks, thugs, drug addicts and poor pensioners, it is an epicentre of crimes and violence.
It was rightfully given the nickname, ‘<color=information>The Black Shack</color>’, for its dark blue, almost black exterior walls.
I have been living here ever since it first opened.
Back then, this was the growing part of the city with a youthful exuberance.
But not long after, as the council went bust, it was deserted,\ forgotten.
Claimed as territories by various gangs, it is a place that even police will actively avoid.
Most of my old neighbours moved away given its infamous reputation.
I am among the last few still here.\ I have nowhere else to go.
As I was still preoccupied by that exotic cigar smell, I was brought back to reality by a loud scream somewhere above.
I finally reached the landing of my floor.
An apple sudden popped out of one of my grocery bags and rolled on the ground.
I bent over to reach it.

outcomeText: Fortunately, it was not bruised.
I picked it up and put it into the grocery bag again and fetched the key from my handbag.
As I turned the key, an immense heat and light blasted through and engulfed me.
I felt I was disintegrated and then everything turned dark.
The next time I opened my eyes, I was stuffed with tubes and wires, covered by white bandages in a hospital.
Although I lost my left arm and leg, the doctor said it was a miracle that I survived and woke up after three months in a coma.
The police soon came over and took some notes as I responded by winking.
They informed me that the explosion was most likely caused by a gas leak and triggered by my entry.
My apartment was destroyed.\ The fire spread to neighbouring apartments on my floor, causing major damages too.
With everything gone and massive bills to pay, I have no way out but to end it all.
God, only if I didn’t open the door...
I panted excessively as I finally found some cover inside the janitor’s closet two floors below.
The deafening gunshots were still ringing in my ear.\ That was too close.
Back there, when I picked up the apple that had rolled and jumped down to the stairs below and lifted my head, I caught a glimpse of a man.
Cold.\ Hostile.\ Professional.
Certainly not from this building.
Years of living in this building has trained me to identify people with even just a glance.
He was after me.
I threw away the bags and rushed down the stairs in my fastest speed.
Before he was able to chase after me from above, I had already got into the corridor and sprinted away.
If there was one advantage I had over him, it had to be my knowledge of the layout of the building.
Every corridor, every stairwell, every closet and room...
I hid in the closet listening intently for any movement.
Then I heard a faint voice down the corridor,
“She has fled... But the bomb is still in place... Yes, I understand.”
Then, his footsteps gradually faded away to silence.
This place was no longer safe; that bomb must have been planted in my room.
That’s the only reason why he didn’t kill me in the stairwell in the first place.
An accident waiting to happen.
I had no time nor the ability to think who he was working for, or how my location got compromised.
After about 20 minutes or so, I was sure he had gone and snuck out through one of the back entrances, into the already dark street, unnoticed.
